citation.article-title: Revival of the name Clostridium aceticum.

p.s: Description of Clostridium aceticum sp. nov., nom. rev.

Clostridium aceticum Wieringa 1940 is rod shaped; it is 0.8 to 1.0 μm wide and about 5 μm long when it is grown chemolithotrophically and up to 40 μm long when it is grown with fructose as the substrate. The cells are motile and peritrichous. Round spores are formed in the polar cell region. The Gram reaction is negative. The deoxyribonucleic acid of C. aceticum contains 33 mol% guanine plus cytosine.

Chemolithotrophic growth with molecular hydrogenvand carbon dioxide occurs at 30°C and pH 8.3; 4 mol of molecular hydrogen and 2 mol of carbon dioxide are converted to 1 mol of acetic acid. C. aceticum is also able to grow chemoorganotrophically.
The following substrates are utilized as carbon and energy sources: D-fructose, D-ribose, L-glutamate, L-mdate, L-serine, pyruvate, formate, and ethanol.
The principal metabolic product is acetate.
Depending on the redox grade of the substrate, carbon dioxide is either produced or is required, in the latter case being reduced to acetate.
In contrast to all other clostridial species, C. aceticum is able to grow at the expense of acetate formation from H2 and CO2.
This property is the main difference between C. aceticum and Clostridium formicoaceticum.
Only minor differences have been observed with respect to the ability of these two species to utilize organic substrates.
Methanol serves as a substrate for C. formicoaceticum but not for C. aceticum.
The opposite has been observed for formate.
A detailed comparison of these two species has been presented previously in connection with the description of C. aceticum (2).

The name Clostridium aceticum sp. nov. is here revived for the same organism to which the name was originally applied, in accordance with Rules 27 and 28a and Provisional Rules B2 and B3 of the International Code of Nomenclature of Bacteria (4).
The type strain of C. aceticum (2) is DSM 1496.
